nodes.label: Automated Bone Marrow Cytology System
nodes.summary: An end-to-end deep learning system that automates the analysis of bone marrow aspirate whole slide images, from region selection to cell classification, culminating in a patient-specific cytological summary called a Histogram of Cell Types (HCT).

nodes.label: Problem Domain and Motivation
nodes.summary: Addresses the challenges of traditional bone marrow cytology, which is tedious, subjective, and limited to experienced centers, often leading to diagnostic delays and inter-observer variability.

nodes.label: Inter-observer Variability
nodes.summary: Manual interpretation of aspirate smears is subject to variability between pathologists, which can affect diagnostic consistency.

nodes.label: Labor-Intensive Process
nodes.summary: The process requires manual identification and counting of 300-500 individual cells, which is time-consuming and tedious.

nodes.label: Need for Expertise
nodes.summary: Accurate interpretation requires highly experienced operators, and lack of expertise in smaller centers can lead to misdiagnosis (e.g., up to 12% of MDS cases).

nodes.label: System Architecture and Workflow
nodes.summary: A fully automated, multi-step computational pipeline that processes digital whole slide images (WSIs) to produce a quantitative cell analysis.

nodes.label: Region of Interest (ROI) Detection
nodes.summary: The system first analyzes a bone marrow aspirate WSI to automatically detect and select small regions (tiles) that are suitable for cytological analysis.

nodes.label: Cell Detection and Classification
nodes.summary: Within the selected ROIs, the system identifies all individual bone marrow cells and non-cellular objects, and classifies them into discrete categories.

nodes.label: Histogram of Cell Types (HCT) Generation
nodes.summary: The collective cytomorphological information is aggregated into a novel representation called the HCT, which quantifies the cell class probability distribution.

nodes.label: Core Deep Learning Models
nodes.summary: The system utilizes specific deep learning architectures for its distinct tasks: a DenseNet model for region selection and a YOLO model for cell analysis.

nodes.label: DenseNet for ROI Detection
nodes.summary: A fine-tuned DenseNet model is implemented to rapidly and automatically select appropriate tiles for cytology from the WSI.

nodes.label: YOLO for Cell Analysis
nodes.summary: A 'You Only Look Once' (YOLO) model is used to perform object detection and classification in a single, computationally efficient step.

nodes.label: YOLO Advantages
nodes.summary: YOLO solves both detection and classification problems simultaneously using a regression approach, making it faster than prior methods like R-CNN. The YOLOV4 version is optimized for small object detection.

nodes.label: Histogram of Cell Types (HCT)
nodes.summary: A novel information summary that acts as a 'cytological patient fingerprint' by representing the complete distribution of cell types found in the bone marrow aspirate.

nodes.label: Function
nodes.summary: Quantifies the class probability distribution of all identified bone marrow cell types, providing a comprehensive summary of the patient's cytology.

nodes.label: System Performance and Results
nodes.summary: The system demonstrated high accuracy and precision across its core tasks, validating its potential for clinical support.

nodes.label: ROI Detection Performance
nodes.summary: Achieved 0.97 accuracy and 0.99 ROC AUC in identifying suitable regions for analysis.

nodes.label: Cell Detection and Classification Performance
nodes.summary: Achieved a mean Average Precision (mAP) of 0.75, an average F1-score of 0.78, and a Log-average miss rate of 0.31 for 16 object classes.

nodes.label: Machine-Learning Algorithm for Bone Marrow Cell Differential Counting
nodes.summary: Development and validation of an AI-based algorithm using a Mask R-CNN model to automate the differential counting of nucleated cells in bone marrow aspiration smears.

nodes.label: Objective
nodes.summary: To develop and validate an artificial intelligence (AI)-based algorithm for identifying and classifying nucleated cells in bone marrow (BM) smears to automate differential counting.

nodes.label: Methodology
nodes.summary: The study involved training a Mask R-CNN model on a large, expert-annotated dataset and validating it on a separate multinational clinical dataset.

nodes.label: AI Model
nodes.summary: A Mask Region-based Convolutional Neural Network (Mask R-CNN) was used to detect and classify individual bone marrow cells.

nodes.label: Training Dataset
nodes.summary: The model was trained on a large dataset of expert-annotated images from various disease categories.

nodes.label: Dataset Size
nodes.summary: 542 slides containing 597,222 annotated cells.

nodes.label: Staining Methods
nodes.summary: Slides were stained with Liu’s stain (85.1%) or Wright–Giemsa stain (14.9%).

nodes.label: Annotation Process
nodes.summary: Consensus meetings were held to ensure consistent classification criteria among experts from different institutes.

nodes.label: Validation
nodes.summary: The AI algorithm's performance was evaluated using a multinational clinical dataset from four different centers.

nodes.label: Validation Dataset
nodes.summary: A multinational real-world dataset comprising 200,639 cells from three centers in Taiwan and one in the United States.

nodes.label: Results and Performance
nodes.summary: The AI model demonstrated high accuracy in both testing and validation phases, with strong correlation to manual counting methods.

nodes.label: Testing Performance
nodes.summary: The model achieved an accuracy of 0.94 on the internal testing dataset containing 26,170 cells.

nodes.label: Validation Performance
nodes.summary: On the multinational real-world dataset, the model achieved an overall accuracy of 0.881 in classifying individual cells.

nodes.label: Cell-Specific Precision
nodes.summary: High precision was observed for key cell types: Blasts (0.927), Bands and Polymorphonuclear Neutrophils (0.955), Plasma cells (0.930), and Lymphocytes (0.789).

nodes.label: Correlation with Manual Counting
nodes.summary: A strong correlation (ρ > 0.8) was observed between AI and manual differential counting percentages for most cell categories.

nodes.label: Challenges in Development
nodes.summary: The paper highlights significant challenges in data collection, image acquisition, and annotation for developing AI models for BM cell analysis.

nodes.label: Data Collection
nodes.summary: Difficult to collect adequate high-quality BM samples covering a wide range of hematological disorders, especially rare diseases.

nodes.label: Image Acquisition
nodes.summary: Capturing digital images of BM smears is not routine, and whole-slide scanning with oil lenses is time-consuming and impractical.

nodes.label: Annotation
nodes.summary: The process is time-consuming, requires scarce expertise, and is complicated by inter-institute variations in classification criteria.

nodes.label: Conclusion
nodes.summary: The developed AI algorithm was clinically validated, can simultaneously locate and classify BM cells, and shows potential for automating BM differential counting in clinical practice.
